pageData.text: A copper(II) chloride aqueous solution is in equilibrium with copper hexahydrate. This lab investigates how this equilibrium can be shifted to the right or left by changing the temperature and concentration of the reactants or products. The shifts in equilibrium can be monitored by changes in the color of the solution, as more products or more reactants are produced.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Water (bottled or purified)
Ice
Table salt (sodium chloride, NaCl)
White paper (8½ x 11 in.)

pageData.text: Bottled or purified water should be used because they lack most of the impurities that are found in tap water. Water that has been filtered through a water purifier (e.g., Brita<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or PUR<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) works well.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Understand what it means when a reaction is in equilibrium.
Explore <button class='glossary-text'>Le Châtelier’s principle</button>.
Determine the influence of the common ion effect on an equilibrium reaction.
Determine the effect of temperature on an equilibrium reaction.
Determine the effect of concentration on an equilibrium reaction.

pageData.text: A carbonated drink is a system in equilibrium while it sits on the shelf. When a fresh carbonated drink is opened the characteristic hiss is produced as the carbon dioxide (CO2) gas in the headspace of the container exits the system and disperses throughout the room at large. The liquid portion produces small bubbles of dissolved CO2 gas leaving the liquid phase and trying to re-establish equilibrium in the headspace. However, because the container is now open, the CO2 gas would have to fill the room to re-establish equilibrium between the liquid and gas phases, which is impossible. So, an open beverage will eventually become “flat” as all the dissolved CO2 leaves the liquid phase and escapes out of the open container. A flat beverage lacks the bite-on-the-tongue characteristic of a carbonated beverage. This bite comes from the carbonic acid (H2CO3) that comes from CO2 dissolved in the liquid phase. When this CO2 leaves the liquid phase, only water - and a flat beverage - are left behind.

pageData.desc: A carbonated beverage in a clear glass with ice. Bubbles are fizzing forcibly at the surface of the beverage.
pageData.altText: A carbonated beverage in a clear glass with ice. Bubbles are fizzing forcibly at the surface of the beverage.

pageData.text: A chemical reaction occurs when reactants react with each other to form products. If the reaction is unidirectional, reactions in which the reactants create products and the products cannot convert back to the reactant, then the reaction is called an <button class='glossary-text'>irreversible reaction</button>. Another type of reaction is a <button class='glossary-text'>reversible reaction</button>, where the forward reaction forms the products, and a reverse reaction reforms the original reactants. In a reversible reaction, the reactants and products are never fully consumed – they are constantly reacting and being produced. At the beginning of the reversible reaction (time 0), there are no products. When the reactants collide, the forward reaction starts forming products. As the product concentration increases, a reverse reaction occurs in which some of the products are converted back into reactants. Eventually, the rate of the reverse reaction equals the rate of the forward reaction, and a state of <button class='glossary-text'>dynamic equilibrium</button> is reached.

When a dynamic equilibrium is reached, the concentrations of the reactants and products remain fixed, but this does not mean that the forward and reverse reactions have stopped. Reactants are still being converted into products, and products are still being converted into reactants. However, the rates of conversion for the forward and reverse reactions are the same after a given period of time, thus resulting in no net change in concentrations. A good analogy is the act of walking down an “up” escalator at the same speed as the escalator moves upward. There will be no change in your position due to the balance of the opposing motions. Figure 1 depicts a graph showing the equilibrium that is established for colorless N2O4 and amber-colored NO2 after a brief period of time.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Graph showing concentration vs time of two chemical species. When the concentration vs time is no longer changing relative to each species, it is in equilibrium.

pageData.text:
How is the equilibrium for NO2 established? Initially, only the forward reaction occurs, as N2O4, which is colorless, changes into NO2, which is amber. This is demonstrated in the following equation: 57.2 kJ + N2O4(g) → 2NO2(g)
        colorless            amber
However, in a short period of time, a reverse reaction takes place, and some of the NO2 reacts to form N2O4 until a exists between the two compounds.57.2 kJ + N2O4(g) ⇄ 2NO2(g)
        colorless            amber

After that, the concentrations remain at fixed values because the rate of the forward reaction () equals the rate of the reverse reaction ().Note that heat is a reactant in the above forward reaction. The enthalpy value (heat energy; ΔH°) for this reaction under standard conditions is 57.2 kJ. This value is positive for endothermic reactions because energy is consumed in the reaction. If this enthalpy had been negative (–57.2 kJ), the forward reaction would have been exothermic, with the heat value appearing as a product on the right side of the equation, as shown here: N2O4(g) ⇄ 2NO2(g) + 57.2 kJ.

pageData.question: Which is the best example of an irreversible reaction?

options.text: C<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>5</sub>OH (aq) + 3 O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) → 2 CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) + 3 H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O (g)
N<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>  ⇋  2 NO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>
H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) + I<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) ⇋ 2 HI (g)

H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> (l) + H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O(l) ⇌ HCO<sup class='bodySupscript'>-3</sup>(aq) + H<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>O+(aq)
2 SO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) + O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (g) ⇋ 2 SO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> (g)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Typically, reversable reactions have two arrows pointing in opposite directions (⇋). These reactions can proceed in both the forward and reverse directions, hence they are reversible.

pageData.question: What distinguishes a reversible from an irreversible reaction?

options.text: A reversible reaction can proceed in the forward and the reverse directions.
An irreversible reaction can proceed in both the forward and the reverse directions.
A reversible reaction can proceed in both cold and hot environments.
A reversible reaction is also called the forward reaction; an irreversible reaction is also called the reverse reaction.
A reversible reaction is also called the reverse reaction; an irreversible reaction is also called the forward reaction.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A reversible reaction can proceed in both the forward reaction and the reverse reaction directions, an irreversible reaction cannot.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A chemical reaction occurs when reactants react with each other to form products. If the reaction is unidirectional, reactions in which the reactants create products and the products cannot convert back to the reactant, then the reaction is called an irreversible reaction. Another type of reaction is a reversible reaction, where the forward reaction forms the products, and a reverse reaction reforms the original reactants. In a reversible reaction, the reactants and products are never fully consumed – they are constantly reacting and being produced.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A chemical reaction occurs when reactants react with each other to form products. If the reaction is unidirectional, reactions in which the reactants create products and the products cannot convert back to the reactant, then the reaction is called an irreversible reaction. Another type of reaction is a reversible reaction, where the forward reaction forms the products, and a reverse reaction reforms the original reactants. In a reversible reaction, the reactants and products are never fully consumed – they are constantly reacting and being produced.

pageData.text: In industry, the challenge with reversible reactions is to keep the products from decomposing back into reactants. Chemical engineers prefer a 100% product yield from a reaction. Such is the case for ammonia production. Fritz Haber, a German chemist, won the 1918 Nobel Prize in chemistry for developing the Haber process. This process involves taking nitrogen directly from the atmosphere and combining it with hydrogen to produce ammonia (NH3), which is a vital component of inorganic fertilizers and explosives.N2(g) + 3H2(g) ⇄ 2NH3(g) + heatWhen the temperature, pressure, and reactant concentrations are normal, the percent yield of ammonia is quite low, due to its decomposition. However, as Henri Le Châtelier discovered in the late 1800s, placing a stress on a reaction at equilibrium can force it to make more products or reactants. A stress can be a change in temperature or concentration. If the reactants or products are gases, the stress can be a change in pressure for the whole reaction system, like the inside of an enclosed tank. states that if a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress.

To efficiently produce NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>, chemical engineers need to shift the equilibrium to the right (the product side). This is achieved by concurrently increasing the concentrations of N<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and removing the ammonia gas (NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>) as soon as it is formed. This forces the reaction to the right to lower the concentration of the additional N<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and to replace the NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>. At the same time, heat is removed, thus further shifting the reaction to the right to replace the removed heat. The pressure is increased, which also shifts the reaction to the right to relieve the excess pressure. In this case, two moles of NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> exert less pressure than four moles of reactants. The simultaneous application of all three stresses (concentration, heat, and pressure) brings about an “optimum yield” of NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> for the reaction.

pageData.desc: The simultaneous application of increased reactant concentration, heat removal, and increased pressure to bring about an optimum yield of ammonia gas from the reaction between nitrogen and hydrogen gases.
pageData.altText: The simultaneous application of increased reactant concentration, heat removal, and increased pressure to bring about an optimum yield of ammonia gas from the reaction between nitrogen and hydrogen gases.

pageData.question: Which statement best describes Le Châtelier’s principle?

options.text: If a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress.
If a stress is placed upon an open system at equilibrium, the reaction will always shift to decrease the temperature to avoid explosions.
If a stress is placed upon a reaction in a closed container at room temperature, the reaction will generate product slower because the closed container limits volume.
If a system is at thermal equilibrium, the reaction will shift to remain stressed, thus producing product.
If a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will resist the stress by producing no more product until the volume of the container is decreased.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Le Châtelier’s principle states that if a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress.

pageData.question:
Which of the following stresses on a system containing the chemical reaction below would result in more product being formed?
N2 (g) + 3H2 (g) ⇋ 2NH3 (g) + Heat

options.text: cooling the system
heating the system
removing N<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> gas from the system
removing H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> gas from the system
adding NH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> to the system

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If heat is removed by cooling the system, the reaction will shift further to the right to replace the removed heat. This results in an increase in products while the system is under this stress.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Henri Le Châtelier discovered in the late 1800s, placing a stress on a reaction at equilibrium can force it to make more products or reactants. A stress can be a change in temperature or concentration. If the reactants or products are gases, the stress can be a change in pressure for the whole reaction system, like the inside of an enclosed tank. Le Châtelier’s principle states that if a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Henri Le Châtelier discovered in the late 1800s, placing a stress on a reaction at equilibrium can force it to make more products or reactants. A stress can be a change in temperature or concentration. If the reactants or products are gases, the stress can be a change in pressure for the whole reaction system, like the inside of an enclosed tank. Le Châtelier’s principle states that if a stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress.

pageData.text:
When copper(II) chloride is dissolved in water, the following reaction steps take place until an equilibrium is established:CuCl2(s) → Cu2+(aq) + 2Cl- (aq)Cu2+(aq) + 6H2O(l) → Cu(H2O)62+(aq)Cu(H2O)62+(aq) + 4Cl-(aq) ⇋ CuCl42-(aq) + 6H2O(l)
                            Blue              Green
If holds, the equilibrium should be shifted by adding or removing either chloride ion (Cl-) or water (H2O). Adding more chloride ion is called the “common ion” effect. In this investigation, the chloride ion is added and removed by using a sodium chloride solution and a silver nitrate solution, respectively, as shown in the reactions on the next page.NaCl(s) → Na+(aq) + Cl-(aq)AgNO3(s) → Ag+(aq) + NO3-(aq)Ag+(aq) + Cl-(aq) → AgCl(s)To monitor the shift in equilibrium, the color of the reaction mixture is observed. A blue color indicates a shift to the left, due to an excess of the Cu(H2O)62+ complex. A green color indicates a shift to the right, due to an excess of the CuCl42- complex.

The second objective of this investigation is to determine if the word “heat” should be written on the right or left side. Many reactions either consume heat (endothermic, heat is a reactant) or produce heat (exothermic, heat is a product).Le Châtelier’s principle states that when a stress is applied to a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress. In this case, the stress will be temperature. By applying heat (hot water bath) or removing heat (cold water bath), the change in color (green or blue) for the reaction will indicate whether the word “heat” should be written on the left or right side.Remember that a reaction at equilibrium tries to maintain status quo. For example, if heat is added to an endothermic reaction, which has heat as a reactant, the reaction will shift to the product side, thus making more products and absorbing the added heat. If heat is taken away, the reaction will shift to the reactant side to make more reactants and heat. The heat that is produced replaces the heat that is removed.

pageData.question: In this investigation, copper(II) chloride will be dissolved in water until equilibrium is established. You will explore Le Châtelier’s principle by shifting the equilibrium of this reaction using the common ion effect. Which of the following is the common ion for this investigation?

options.text: chloride ion (Cl<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>)
copper ion (Cu<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup>)
water (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O)
hydroxide ion (OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>)
hydrogen ion (H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The equilibrium should be shifted by adding or removing either chloride ion (Cl<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>) or water (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O). In this investigation, the chloride ion is added and removed by using a sodium chloride solution and a silver nitrate solution, respectively.

pageData.question:
How will you observe if the reaction below shifts to the left during this investigation?
Cu(H2O)62+(aq) + 4Cl-(aq) ⇋ CuCl42-(aq) + 6H2O(l)

options.text: The reaction becomes blue in color.
The reaction becomes green in color.
The reaction temperature decreases.
The reaction produces a precipitate.
The reaction volume increases.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When the reverse reaction takes place and more reactants are produced, the reaction turns blue. When the forward reaction takes place and more products are produced, the reaction turns green.

In this investigation, the chloride ion is added and removed by using a sodium chloride solution and a silver nitrate solution, respectively.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by preparing a concentrated sodium chloride solution. 
In Activity 1, you will add copper (II) chloride solution to the test tubes. Then add sodium chloride solution to the test tubes. Next compare the solution colors. 
In Activity 2, you will add silver nitrate solution to a test tube from activity 1. Then compare solution colors from Activities 1 and 2. 
In Activity 3, you will add water to two test tubes from activity 1. Then compare solution colors from activities 1-3. 
In Activity 4, you will prepare a hot water bath. Then prepare an ice water bath. Next place a test tube from activity 3 in one of the water baths. Then compare the solution color to the other activity 3 solution. You will then determine if the direction of equilibrium shifted. Repeat this activity for the other water bath.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes a chemical reaction in a state of dynamic equilibrium?

options.text: The rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal.
The once irreversible reaction is now reversible.
The reaction has multiple forward and reverse reaction possibilities.
The reactants are fully consumed into products.
The concentrations of the reactants and products fluctuate.

assestmentData.question: A chemical reaction has an enthalpy value (ΔH) of –87.6 kJ. Which of the following best describes this chemical reaction?

options.text: exothermic
endothermic
reversible
irreversible
dynamic

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios best describes Le Chatelier's principle?

options.text: A reaction at equilibrium produces more product when the temperature of the reaction system is increased.
A reaction reaches equilibrium when the concentration of the products is increased.
A reaction reaches equilibrium when the reactants are filtered out of the system.
A reaction at equilibrium remains at equilibrium despite an increase in the pressure of the reaction system.
A reaction at equilibrium produces more reactant spontaneously after so much time has elapsed.

assestmentData.question:
The chemical reaction below is at equilibrium. If reactant B is removed from the reaction system, which of the following is most likely to occur?
A + B --> C

options.text: The reaction will shift to produce more reactants.
The reaction will shift to produce more product.
The reaction will remain at equilibrium.
The reaction rate will slow down.
The reaction will stop.

assestmentData.question:
The chemical reaction below is at equilibrium. If the reaction vessel is cooled, which of the following is most likely to occur?
A + B --> C + D + heat

options.text: The reaction will shift to produce more products.
The reaction will shift to produce more reactants.
The reaction will remain at equilibrium.
The reaction rate will slow down.
The reaction will stop.

assestmentData.question: In this investigation, you will dissolve copper (II) chloride in water to create a reaction at equilibrium. You will then use which of the following stressors to shift the reaction equilibrium?

options.text: adding chloride ions
removing water
increasing the pressure
placing the reaction in sunlight
placing the reaction in the dark

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass Erlenmeyer flask. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety hazards are associated with both the copper (II) chloride and silver nitrate solutions provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: They cause skin and eye irritation.
They are respiratory tract irritants.
They are corrosive to metals.
They will stain skin and clothing.
They are highly flammable.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.

Prepare 15 mL of a concentrated sodium chloride solution as follows:
  1. Tare a weigh boat on the pocket balance by pressing the right button for a readout of 0.0 g.
  2. Weigh out 4.5 g of NaCl in the weigh boat.
The electronic balance shuts off after 1 minute of inactivity. Measurements of mass should be made within this amount of time.

1. Bend the weigh boat in half, and pour the NaCl into the 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
  2. Use the 10-mL graduated cylinder to add 15 mL of water to the flask (10 mL + 5 mL).
  3. Gently swirl the solution until all NaCl crystals are dissolved.
  4. If the salt crystals do not dissolve, heat the solution in the microwave in 5-second increments. Gently swirl the flask after each heating cyle. Flask may be hot!

In Activity 1, you will observe the common ion effect by comparing the color of a control sample of 0.5 M copper(II) chloride solution against the color of copper(II) chloride solution mixed with increasing amounts of concentrated sodium chloride solution.
Use a grease pencil to number the test tubes (1–5), and place them in the front row of the test tube rack.
Add 2 mL (40 drops) of the copper(II) chloride solution to each of the 5 test tubes.
Test tube #1 will be the control and reference for color. Nothing will be added to test tube #1. Record this color in Data Table 1.
Using the 10-mL graduated cylinder, measure 1 mL of the concentrated salt solution from the 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask, and add it to test tube #2. Gently swirl to mix the solution.
Measure 2 mL of the concentrated salt solution, and add it to test tube #3. Gently swirl to mix the solution.
Measure 4 mL of the concentrated salt solution, and add it to test tube #4. Gently swirl to mix the solution.
Measure 4 mL of the concentrated salt solution, and add it to test tube #5. Gently swirl to mix the solution.
You will need both of these tubes for temperature comparisons later in the lab.
Test tube #4 and test tube #5 will be used for Activity 4 (temperature changes). Keep these solutions and test tubes.
Compare the colors of the solutions in test tubes #2–5 to that in test tube #1. Use white paper as a background to assist with view and color comparisons.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of the five solutions.
Record the colors in the appropriate columns in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will continue to observe the common ion effect by adding silver nitrate solution to one of the test tubes from Activity 1 and comparing the color of the solution against the solutions from Activity 1.

typeBefore.text: Be sure to rinse out the 10-mL graduated cylinder with bottled/purified water before starting this activity to prevent cross contamination.

pageData.text: Add 1 mL (20 drops) of silver nitrate solution to test tube #3 and gently swirl to mix the solution.
Allow the solution to sit for 5 minutes.
Record all observations in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of test tube #3 and test tube #1.

In Activity 3, you will observe the effect of adding water to the reaction. You will add water to two of the test tubes from Activity 1 and compare the color of the solutions against the solutions from Activities 1 and 2.

typeBefore.text: Be sure to rinse out the 10-mL graduated cylinder with bottled/purified water before starting this activity to prevent cross contamination.

pageData.text: Add 3 mL of water to test tube #4, and stir with a pipet.
Compare the color of the solution in test tube #4 to the color of the solution in test tube #5.
Record these colors in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of test tube #4 and test tube #5.
Add 3 mL of water to test tube #5, and stir with a pipet.
Keep all test tubes for the next activity.

In Activity 4, you will observe the effect of temperature on the equilibrium of the reaction. You will continue to use the two test tubes from Activity 3: one test tube will remain at room temperature, the other will be placed into a hot water bath first, then an ice water bath. At each temperature, the color of the solution in each test tube will be compared.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Effect of Temperature on Equilibrium (13 steps)
pages.title: Effect of Temperature on Equilibrium (13 steps)

pageData.text: Record the temperature and color of the solution in test tube #4 in Data Table 2.
Fill a 250-mL beaker with hot tap water (approximately 65 °C).
Record the temperature of the hot water bath in Data Table 2.

If the hot tap water is not > 60 °C, heat the water in a microwave for 1-minute intervals until the water is hot enough. The plastic beaker is microwave-safe, but the thermometer is not. Do not microwave the thermometer.
Fill a 10-oz plastic cup half full with ice cubes, and then add water.
Record the temperature of the cold water bath in Data Table 2.
Place test tube #5 into the hot water bath. Gently stir the solution with a thermometer until the temperature is approximately 50 °C.
Compare the color of the solution in test tube #5 to the solution in test tube #4 at room temperature.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of test tube #4 and test tube #5.
Record the direction of the equilibrium shift in Data Table 2 by observing the final color.
Place test tube #5 into the cold water bath. Gently stir the solution with the thermometer until the temperature is < 10 °C.
Compare the color of the solution in test tube #5 to the color of the solution in test tube #4 at room temperature.
Record the direction of the equilibrium shift in Data Table 2 by observing the final color.

text: Mix any remaining silver nitrate solutions with a few milliliters of sodium chloride solution. A white precipitate of silver chloride will form. This can be absorbed into some paper towels and disposed of in the trash.

All reaction solutions not containing silver nitrate and remaining copper chloride solutions can be poured down the drain with running water. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Clean and dry the lab equipment, and then return them to the equipment kit.
Clean and sanitize the workspace.

pageData.title: Questions
text: What is the “common ion” that you added to test tubes #2–5?
How does the common ion affect the equilibrium reaction as the amount of NaCl solution increases from 1–4 mL?
Based upon the color, in which direction does the equilibrium shift?
Write an equation showing what happens when AgNO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> is added, and explain why the equilibrium shifts.

Explain the equilibrium shift that occurs when water is added to the original equilibrium reaction.
Cu(H2O)62+(aq) + 4Cl-(aq) ⇄ CuCl42–(aq) + 6H2O(l)
                            Blue              Green

header: Direction of Shift (reactants or products) (← or →)

text: Given the equilibrium equation for a general reaction, A + B ⇄  C + D, explain what happens to the reactants and products from time 0 until the time at which the reaction reaches equilibrium.

Given this reaction at equilibrium, C(s) + CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>(g) ⇄  2CO(g) (∆H° = 119kJ), explain the changes that would occur when the following stresses are applied or removed for this reaction.

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of Elements
Figure 1: Graph showing concentration vs time of two chemical species. When the concentration vs time is no longer changing relative to each species, it is in equilibrium.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by preparing a concentrated sodium chloride solution. 
In Activity 1, you will add copper (II) chloride solution to the test tubes. Then add sodium chloride solution to the test tubes. Next compare the solution colors. 
In Activity 2, you will add silver nitrate solution to a test tube from activity 1. Then compare solution colors from Activities 1 and 2. 
In Activity 3, you will add water to two test tubes from activity 1. Then compare solution colors from activities 1-3. 
In Activity 4, you will prepare a hot water bath. Then prepare an ice water bath. Next place a test tube from activity 3 in one of the water baths. Then compare the solution color to the other activity 3 solution. You will then determine if the direction of equilibrium shifted. Repeat this activity for the other water bath.

data.title: Dynamic equilibrium
data.content: A state in which the rate of the reverse reaction equals the rate of the forward reaction

data.title: Irreversible reaction
data.content: A undirectional reaction in which the reactants create products and the products cannot convert back to the reactant

data.title: Le Châtelier’s principle
data.content: If stress is placed upon a reaction at equilibrium, the reaction will shift to relieve that stress

data.title: Reversible reaction
data.content: A reaction that can proceed forward or in reverse: the forward reaction forms products and the reverse reaction reforms the reactants; in this type of reaction the reactants and products are never fully consumed but instead are constantly reacting and being produced
